Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Children in these neighborhoods primarily ingest lead from dust in their homes and yards.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Living in neighborhoods with high concentrations of older homes; mentioned as being primarily affected by lead poisoning

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Kids raised in Memphis’ suburbs face little risk of lead poisoning since few homes there were built after 1978.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Living in suburban areas with fewer older homes; mentioned for comparative risk assessment

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Children in Cordova are far safer from lead poisoning than kids in Midtown. And children in Arlington are much better off than their counterparts in North Memphis.
Unnamed Group of People.Name of Source: Children in various neighborhoods (Cordova, Midtown, Arlington, North Memphis)
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Residing in different neighborhoods with varying levels of risk for lead poisoning; used for comparative analysis

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: According to the U.S. Census Bureau, about 96% of residents in South Memphis are Black, and about 91% of homes were built prior to 1978.
Document Sources.Source Justification: Authority on demographic and housing data; used to provide statistical evidence of neighborhood compositions and housing ages

Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Author of the article; expertise in housing and development reporting

Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Publisher of the article; focused on poverty, power, and policy in Memphis
Recommended point of contact for scheduling free lead testing

Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: Shelby County Lead Hazard Control program
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Recommended point of contact for home lead testing
Alternative recommended point of contact for home lead testing
